What complicates the fire season down here in the desert is those fine fields, the grasses and that brush.
They burn fast with the strong wind, and they spread faster than people, I think, realize.
The part of the Tonto National Forest closest to Phoenix gets around 50,000 visitors a day during the summer, and any one of them could inadvertently start a major wildfire.
In these desert areas, fire isn't a natural part, and so we don't do prescribed fires because fire is not a good part of the system.
It kills cactus and, really, isn't something that we want to see.

And we feel this is really in that spirit, that we provide a resource to the community that individuals would not be able to have access to on their own.
